entries.meaning: comparative form of trim: more trim
One who trims, arranges, fits, or ornaments.
examples: It put me to endless expense of having roof-men, gutter-men and tree-trimmers. At last I gave the grim order, “Cut her down.”
My new electric shaver has a beard trimmer attachment.

entries.meaning: (nautical) A member of the crew who trims the sails.
examples: Hyponyms: wing trimmer, headsail trimmer, mainsheet trimmer

entries.meaning: Someone who fluctuates between opposing factions, political parties etc., according to current interest, a flip-flopper.
examples: Thus Halifax was a Trimmer on principle.

entries.meaning: (architecture) A beam into which are framed the ends of headers in floor framing, as when a hole is to be left for stairs, or to avoid bringing joists near chimneys.
(shipping, historical) A person employed to rearrange the coal in the hold of a vessel, so that it fills the vessel without forming a conical blockage.
(mining, historical) A device for storing coal in gradually increasing piles made by building up at the point of the cone or top of the prism.
(fishing) A float bearing a baited hook and line, used in fishing for pike.
(dated) One who or that which trims, or rebukes or reproves; a scold.
examples: Mr. Hazeldean wrote him such a trimmer that it could not but produce an unconciliatory reply.
